content.raw:
This is not a `setuptools` problem AFAIK, I'm using the current version.

There is a very unsatisfying hack that might fix this, but haven't tried it and it's as far as I've gotten:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/24686838/distributing-a-binary-utility-in-setuptools

content.raw:
> I'm proposing not importing anything from future_builtins at all.

Sounds great to me.

As far as packaging is concerned, going forward setuptools is the way to go. There really should be no reference to ez_setup since it can cause issues if the module is not installed. It was used as a bootstrap to make sure setuptools is installed but technically now there's the module 'ensurepip' available in 2.7.9 and all newer versions of 3.5+.

I think you just take out the ez_setup import (along with use_setuptools) without issue. I haven't tested this though.

As far as the unicode decoding error is concerned it's probably an issue with the version of setuptools you have installed. This was really common with our numpy installation testing. I think upgrading your version of setuptools should fix the issue.

For reference here's the guidelines we're following regarding python packaging:
https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/distributing/
content.html:
I'm proposing not importing anything from future_builtins at all.

Sounds great to me.

As far as packaging is concerned, going forward setuptools is the way to go. There really should be no reference to ez_setup since it can cause issues if the module is not installed. It was used as a bootstrap to make sure setuptools is installed but technically now there's the module 'ensurepip' available in 2.7.9 and all newer versions of 3.5+.

I think you just take out the ez_setup import (along with use_setuptools) without issue. I haven't tested this though.

As far as the unicode decoding error is concerned it's probably an issue with the version of setuptools you have installed. This was really common with our numpy installation testing. I think upgrading your version of setuptools should fix the issue.

For reference here's the guidelines we're following regarding python packaging: https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/distributing/

content.raw:
I'm proposing not importing anything from `future_builtins` at all. Everything but `ascii` is already available in py2.7, and the `ascii` function is not used in `genomedata`.

I actually tried building genomedata under py3 after removing the `future_builtins` import statements, and there is apparently an even stickier issue having to do with compiling C code under py3.

The key error below is the `UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0xcf in position 0: invalid continuation byte` part, which from stackoverflow searches seems to be a common interaction between `setuptools` and compiled libraries in `python3`. I didn't see any leads on how to fix this so it may take some digging.

Python package distribution is an eternally confusing issue and I just want to confirm that you really want to use `setuptools` and `ez_setup` moving forward. If there's a better / preferred way I'm happy to look into it.

```

$ python3 setup.py build

running build_scripts

src/genomedata_load_data.c:851:13: warning: format specifies type 'unsigned long long' but the argument has type 'genomic_position_type' (aka 'unsigned long') [-Wformat]
            buf_len);
            ^~~~~~~
1 warning generated.

##################################################
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python3/3.5.0/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.5/lib/python3.5/tokenize.py", line 392, in find_cookie

UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0xcf in position 0: invalid continuation byte

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

    cmd_obj.run()
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python3/3.5.0/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.5/lib/python3.5/distutils/command/build.py", line 135, in run
    self.run_command(cmd_name)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python3/3.5.0/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.5/lib/python3.5/distutils/cmd.py", line 313, in run_command
    self.distribution.run_command(command)

  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python3/3.5.0/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.5/lib/python3.5/tokenize.py", line 433, in detect_encoding
```

content.html:
I'm proposing not importing anything from future_builtins at all. Everything but ascii is already available in py2.7, and the ascii function is not used in genomedata.

I actually tried building genomedata under py3 after removing the future_builtins import statements, and there is apparently an even stickier issue having to do with compiling C code under py3.

The key error below is the UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0xcf in position 0: invalid continuation byte part, which from stackoverflow searches seems to be a common interaction between setuptools and compiled libraries in python3. I didn't see any leads on how to fix this so it may take some digging.

Python package distribution is an eternally confusing issue and I just want to confirm that you really want to use setuptools and ez_setup moving forward. If there's a better / preferred way I'm happy to look into it.

content.raw: I'd think so. It looks like a lot (if not all) of the future_builtins should be in at least 2.7. Is it not possible to remove in the import on 2.7?
content.html: I'd think so. It looks like a lot (if not all) of the future_builtins should be in at least 2.7. Is it not possible to remove in the import on 2.7?

content.raw:
I will incorporate / roll back these changes.

Do you want `python3 setup.py install` to run with this patch? Including `future_builtins` breaks python3 as its not included in the py3 distribution.
content.html:
I will incorporate / roll back these changes.

Do you want python3 setup.py install to run with this patch? Including future_builtins breaks python3 as its not included in the py3 distribution.

content.raw:
Thanks for helping with this.

> I didn't enforce py2.7+ anywhere because there are a variety of ways to do that and I'm sure Michael has a favorite way

This should be enforced in `setup.py`.

> 2to3 also changed a variety of interface details (iteritems to items, xrange to range etc)

Can we not do this for now? 2.7 `iteritems` = 3.5 `items` but 2.7 `iteritems` != 2.7 `items`.

> - added sizes command to genomedata-info

Can you please make this a separate pull request? If this is just Py3 readiness it should be separate from a new feature.

Also please add `NEWS` describing changes (with your name).

After you respond to these items, @ericr86 will do a line-by-line review and then I will.

Regarding the command-line interface I would rather not change it for now because it would break old scripts. It would require a new minor release at least and a separate discussion.

Thanks!
Michael
content.html:
Thanks for helping with this.

I didn't enforce py2.7+ anywhere because there are a variety of ways to do that and I'm sure Michael has a favorite way

This should be enforced in setup.py.

2to3 also changed a variety of interface details (iteritems to items, xrange to range etc)

Can we not do this for now? 2.7 iteritems = 3.5 items but 2.7 iteritems != 2.7 items.

  • added sizes command to genomedata-info

Can you please make this a separate pull request? If this is just Py3 readiness it should be separate from a new feature.

Also please add NEWS describing changes (with your name).

After you respond to these items, @ericr86 will do a line-by-line review and then I will.

Regarding the command-line interface I would rather not change it for now because it would break old scripts. It would require a new minor release at least and a separate discussion.

Thanks! Michael

update.description:
In response to issue #16.

Finally fixed `argparse` in `load_genomedata`. Added new command lines to docs.

See the closed pull request #10 for description.
update.title: Py3 compat
